The County Court was to meet in quarterly sessions or terms throughout the year to dispose of the probate and civil business of the County. All business brought to the Court's attention was listed in the Minute Books of the County. Any documents submitted to the Court during these sessions were recorded in the Record Books. In the early years the Clerk recorded these items as he found time to do so. Therefore, many items took their time appearing in the record books. There may be a gap of several months between the official appearance in Court (Minute Books) and the actual recording of the documents (Record Books) produced at the Court appearance. The first-named individual in each item recorded is usually deceased. The estate was in need of investigation by the Court, who in turn either heard the deceased's representative, an Executor, or appointed an individual, an Administrator, to process the deceased's estate The Record Books contain documents involving the following: 1. Bills of sales of slaves 2. Powers of Attorney - allowing another to represent you in dealing with the courts of Rutherford County^ 3. Divisions of lands associated with heirs of an estate. 4. Apprenticeships 5. Prenuptial agreements 6. Surveys - usually prior to 1810. 7. Wills - Wills were not placed in a separate book until well after the Civil War. 8. Widow's Allowances - usually an allotment of foodstuffs, clothing, etc. for the support of the widow and her family for at least one year following the decease of her husband or until the estate could be settled. 9. Inventories of estates - an itemized list of all property, personal and real, owned by the deceased, as well as outstanding debts to the deceased or debts the deceased owed another individual. 10. Sales of estates - an itemized list of the buyers of all goods and property sold by the Executor/Administrator. 11. Settlements of estates - statement of expenses in the settling of the estate as reviewed by a commission composed by three or more outstanding citizens named by the Court to the final accounting of the Executor/ Administrator. 12. Guardian's Returns - A named guardian's yearly reports of money spent on the minor heirs of the deceased, or income received for the heir's support. 13. Division of Property - this entailed the apportioning of the valued items to heirs of an estate, usually slaves. A sincere attempt has been made to spell the words correctly as they have been written. However, in some instances a name will be spelled several different ways within a single record. A notation is usually made concerning the variations. Also, 19th century handwriting is difficult to read at best and errors of deciphering the names, in some instances, is next to impossible. Every attempt was made to give the correct name.
